I'm working with some terms like

⊢ cexp (c * ↑(n1 + n2)) = cexp (c * ↑n1) * cexp (c * ↑n2)

I can't use distributivity, as long as the coercion is applied to n1+n2 instead of separately. How do I convert ↑(n1 + n2) to ↑n1 + ↑n2 or somehow use mul_add and other distributivity laws without doing that?
There will be a theorem that you can rw with that distributes the arrow as you describe, but it will depend on what the arrows mean.
def cexp_zmult (c : ℂ) (n1 n2 : ℤ) : cexp (c * ↑(n1 + n2)) = cexp (c * n1) * cexp (c * n2) := by
trying to do rw [mul_add c n1 n2] but the coercion of the sum screws it up
Thanks, I didn't think I'd find something in the Int docs, should have looked there.
Anthony Peterson has marked this topic as resolved.
